text:
I’ve appreciated the time people have spent commenting on other posts I’ve used for advice so will add a few of ours thus far in our trip - Milan & Venice thus far, previously Sicily .

Basics:

- I’ve been so impressed by the friendliness we’ve encountered - whether in stores at restaurants or on the streets with locals - simply rewarded for trying to speak a few horribly pronounced words of Italian. I suspect most tourists here who speak English don’t make the effort highly advise trying your Italian- you’re rewarded with smiles and so much help/ thoughtfulness.

- heat- we’re heading south so expect things to ch age but Milan & Venice not at all challenging . Early am/ evenings are incredibly pleasant, hasn’t been an issue at all which I’m grateful for as I suspect that will change soon

- safety - maybe I’ll eat my words but it feels like any other big city - be smart , don’t display your wealth , leave passports etc at hotel/ appt , crossbody bag with phone / cards. I let my 18 yr old dtr wander / explore on ver own without worry- yes she gets lots of ( male ) attention but it doesn’t feel unsafe

- trains- like all of Europe they make us (North American’s) who lack this infrastructure/ well developed train transport system look foolish. I’d never fly domestic here . ( esp with luggage loss concerns!) Trains are on time safe & efficient. Get premium / business / executive etc with reserved seats if you can at all afford too- worth it! More space to ensure you can store luggage ( be on time get on early if travelling in high season) they give a drink/ snacks in business/ water / simpler snacks in premium. You get the best countryside tours/ views compared to flying , and save the wasted time of getting to airports early, hassles with clearing security etc & arrive in central parts of wherever you’re going

ETA-
LUGGAGE - we have checked & hand luggage -Just couldn’t pare it down more - it certainly would be wayyyy simpler with only hand so for those who are able to simplify better then I it is likely worth it. But honestly if you’re in reasonable shape and the bags aren’t too heavy it hasn’t been an issue - no space concerns on the trains ( remember though we only know premium / business) or the Venetian water taxis

- just use the search feature in this group & search old posts - so much great info!

MILAN

-we came here as it was an easy entry airport as we went to Iceland first. Big city - certainly beautiful, but if time is ltd with all the charm this country has I wouldn’t prioritize it unless you have other reasons. Many posts have all the main points covered , I’d only add:

The Last supper - absolutely book asap, do the tours if you need to to get a ticket - 3 mos or more prior it sounds like- we saw many disappointed people .

If you are happy to spend a few extra bucks the Aperol bar on the upper floor of the galleria overlooking the Duomo / square was a great place to enjoy a drink & snacks and just take it all in.

The Campari bar off the square at the entry to the galleria is also kinda a must do if you enjoy cocktails/ this kinda thing!

We stayed in the Lombardia area - at least on the weekend super fun nightlife spilling onto the streets- I’m assuming this is one of ( hopefully many) the more LGBTQ friendly areas - which I feel only added to the charm- but if not identifying as such or an ally then maybe you won’t have as much fun as we did.

VENICE -
I loved that we booked a Vrbo & being on the periphery. It’s dirty with tourists but like most places in the world if you’re willing to walk over a few streets / bridges the rewards are so so worth it! Despite being mid July we’d often be the only ones wandering whatever street we were on, had the best antipasti picnic along a canal we basically had to ourselves . It really only takes 10-20 or more minutes walk to get to the centre from most places . Take a diff route each time!

A bonus of staying in an appt ( vs hotel) is a tiny look into local life - for example I loved learning about how things are done differently due to the obvious- something like the garbage collection process is incredibly charming

Water taxis worked so well , easy to get to Murano etc with it too. As long as you’re not pressed for time no need for rhapeddo.

Gondolas- Maybe this is ignorant- but I assume like every professional you get what you pay for. I’m so grateful to whomever here posted their recommendation about Luca! Paid more then the general rate if you go to one of the usual places to catch a tour - but his commentary was so worth it , I’d recommend the longer the better - we did his 75 min tour which takes you to I think 3 diff areas , charming smaller / less busy canals, he’s a 3 rd generation gondolier using his grandfathers boat only one of 19 of the same kind . And yes, he’ll sing to you! For me this level of service was worth paying more for- we saw other gondoliers on their phones, not providing commentary ( only if wanted of course!) , etc .
